prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong based on their situation. The scenario is about a couple where the author pays all the bills because their girlfriend only works part-time. Then, after a small incident where the author made the girlfriend pay for a $40 takeout because he left his wallet, he's considering making her start contributing more to the bills.

First, I need to understand both sides. The author has been paying everything, which might be their arrangement. The girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she's contributing in other ways, like chores or other expenses. The incident was minor, but the author is upset because of her reaction. The question is whether the author is wrong to want her to start paying some bills now over this single event.

I should consider communication. The author hasn't discussed this with his girlfriend. Maybe the girlfriend feels the arrangement was okay before, and the author is changing things suddenly because of one incident. That could be unfair. Also, the takeout was only $40, which isn't a huge amount. The author's reaction might be disproportionate. The girlfriend's attitude might have been due to being asked to pay unexpectedly, especially if she wasn't used to contributing. 

Financial arrangements in relationships can be sensitive. If the author is the sole provider, maybe the girlfriend isn't used to contributing, but that's not necessarily her fault. The author's frustration is understandable, but making her take on more responsibility after one incident without prior discussion could be seen as unfair. The author might be overreacting. Also, the fact that the takeout was a small amount and the author pays everything else, so maybe the girlfriend didn't expect to contribute yet. However, the author might feel entitled to adjust the arrangement, but without communication, it's a problem.

So, the author might be in the wrong because he's making a significant change based on a minor incident without discussing it with his partner. Relationships require communication and mutual agreement on financial matters. Jumping to conclusions after one event, especially a small one, might not be fair. The answer could be A (the author is in the wrong) because he's not considering the existing arrangement and is overreacting. Alternatively, maybe the answer is B (not in the wrong) if it's about principle. But I think the key here is the sudden change and lack of communication. So A.
